awd_titl_txt: Molecular biophysics of motility in cytoskeletal motor proteins
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate the structure and function of two proteins, kinesin and myosin, which belong to category of proteins that are designated as 'molecular motors'. These enzymes use the energy derived from hydrolysis of one of the most common energy storage molecules in cells, adenosine triphosphate, to drive muscle contraction, intracellular transport, cell motility, and cell division. The goal of the project is to understand how these proteins generate motion to perform cellular work. This project will utilize a 'metal-rescue' technology for controlling and modulating the activity of the motor protein by varying the ratio of metal ions that are necessary components for the proteins. This innovative technology will be useful for researchers to reversibly control the activity of multiple different enzymes. The educational aims of this project will fill a gap in the local education system to promote robust science teaching and learning for the next generation of scientists. Underrepresented minorities at the high school level will be educated and trained in STEM research.

The research objective of this project is to define the nucleotide hydrolysis mechanisms of unconventional kinesin and myosin motor proteins using biochemical, structural, biophysical, and advanced mathematical analysis. Myosin and kinesin superfamily motors are cytoskeletal filament-stimulated ATPases that share structural motifs in their active sites which directly interact with the nucleotide and divalent metal cofactor, typically Mg(II). A 'metal-rescue' strategy will be used to control the enzymatic activity and motility of kinesins and myosins and by taking advantage of the differential affinities of Mg(II) and Mn(II) for serine or cysteine residues. Specifically, manipulation of the protein-metal interaction will provide a direct and experimentally reversible strategy to modulate switch-1 closure and, thus, motor motility upon its filament. The ATPase mechanism of wild type and the metal-rescue mutant kinesin-5 motors from Saccharomyces cerevisiae will be defined and the allosteric mechanochemistry of the wild type and metal-rescue mutant of myosin-II motors from Dictyostelium discoideum will be determined. This project will develop a biophysical tool to reversibly control the activity of molecular motors or other P-loop NTPases. This project is supported by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster of the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division in the Directorate for Biological Sciences.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Most cells in our bodies contain miniaturized cellular highways, known as the cytoskeleton, which serve as tracks for transport of material inside cells or that function in cell movement. Our cells also have a series of molecular motor proteins that use chemical energy inside cells to walk along the cytoskeleton. These molecular motors are miraculous machines, where some motors can traverse the entire cell in about 10 seconds. The goal of this project was to understand how these motors use the chemical energy inside cells (ATP) to generate force production or movement along the cytoskeleton tracks. Molecular motors fall into two main classes, those that walk along the microtubule cytoskeleton, which include kinesins and dyneins, and those that move on the actin cytoskeleton, which include both muscle and non-muscle myosins. Earlier structural studies made a major and surprising finding that even though kinesins and myosins have very different amino acid sequences, their three-dimensional structures are quite similar. This suggests that the basic design principles of molecular motors are conserved, but that the ways that they couple ATP hydrolysis to motility must have unique properties in different motors for them to function properly in the cell. The work in this project elucidated basic design principles on three different molecular motor proteins that function either during cell division or in cell motility. These studies provided new insights into the design principles of cellular machines.

In addition to the scientific discovery, this project had broader impacts through training and mentoring of both undergraduate students and high-school students, including URM students from multiple IU sponsored programs. The study of molecular motor proteins provides an ideal learning tool for students to literally ?see? science in action at the molecular scale in addition to learning about the scientific process of data collection, analysis and presentation. In addition, this project provided training and support for two PhD students who have now pursued STEM careers in the biotech industry.

 


Last Modified: 07/12/2021
Modified by: Claire E Walczak
